title: The role of substitution elasticity in Domar aggregation

sections.text:
#### Abstract

The economy-wide production network, i.e., the monetary input-output coefficients, will no longer be stable against the general equilibrium propagation of sectoral productivity shocks, when the substitution elasticities of sectoral production are nonneutral. The associated network transformation hence renders nonlinearity in aggregating sectoral productivity shocks into the economy's output, i.e., Domar aggregation. In this study, we demonstrate the possibility of production networks being transformed into a singular one. We also explore the conditions under which the productivity shocks experience synergism in Domar aggregation.


Keywords Productivity propagation $\cdot$ Elasticity of substitution $\cdot$ Input-output linkages $\cdot$ Singularities $\cdot$ Fallacy of composition

## JEL Classification C67 $\cdot$ D51 $\cdot$ O41

[^0]
[^0]:    Satoshi Nakano
    0000-0003-0424-585X
    Nihon Fukushi University, Tokai, 477-0031, Japan
    E-mail: nakano@n-fukushi.ac.jp
    Kazuhiko Nishimura ( $\boxtimes$ )
    0000-0002-7400-7227

    E-mail: nishimura@lets.chukyo-u.ac.jp

# 1 Introduction 

Suppose all industrial sectors of the entire economy reveal constant returns to scale. Then, for each sector, the unit cost function with pregiven level of productivity becomes scale-free and only dependent on factor prices. Owing to the fact that all commodities are made by means of commodities, while assuming all commodities are produced by different but unique sectors (i.e., no joint production) and that there is only one kind of primary factor not made by means of commodities, the prices of commodities relative to the primary factor are determined as the solution to the general equilibrium system of equations that equilibrate commodity prices to unit costs of sectors. Shephard's lemma nonetheless indicates that input-output coefficients will only be affected by the equilibrium price change, which will only be triggered by the propagation of productivity shocks across all sectors. ${ }^{1}$

The idea of aggregating productivity growths associated with industrial sectors into national aggregate output growth measures is called the Domar aggregation. In a closed economy, aggregate output growth in the above setting essentially equals the aggregated commodity prices via the representative household's indirect utility, where the commodity prices are determined by the sectoral unit cost functions with productivity growths exogenously given. Hulten (1978) claimed that sectoral productivity growths can be mapped into national aggregate output growth by linear aggregation using Domar weights. Linear aggregation of sectoral productivity growths, however, is only possible in an economy where the representative household and all the production sectors aggregate commodities in a Cobb-Douglas fashion, so that the monetary input-output coefficients remain constant. ${ }^{2}$

Accordingly, Acemoglu et al (2012, 2017); Acemoglu and Azar (2020) studied Domar aggregation under Cobb-Douglas technology where Domar weights are the product of representative household's expenditure shares and the (monetary) Leontief inverse. In this case, the volatility of the aggregate output fluctuations will contract disproportionally to the number of sectors whose productivity shocks are being aggregated, owing to the granular property (Gabaix, 2011) of the Leontief inverse. Baqaee and Farhi (2019); Nakano and Nishimura (2021) then studied aggregate fluctuations of an economy comprising non-Cobb-Douglas technology and showed that aggregate fluctuations will have nonnormal tails even if sectoral productivity shocks have normal tails, owing to the nonlinear nature of Domar aggregation that can potentially induce network transformation.

From empirical perspective, Kim et al (2017); Nakano and Nishimura (2024) examined economy-wide propagation of innovation, where innovation is proxied by productivity shocks and their propagation is concerned across the production network of sectors with empirically estimated CES (constant elasticity of substitution) unit cost functions. In this setting, the fixed point solution to the general equilibrium system of equations is solved by way of recursive mapping from factor prices onto commodity unit costs which will globally converge to a unique equilibrium, owing to the concavity of the mapping, if only the solution existed in the positive-finite domain. During the course of analyses, however, there were cases (of productivity shocks) where the recursive mapping experienced nonconvergence, indicating the absence of the solution in the positive-finite domain.

The abovementioned nonlinear Domar aggregation (which thus implies synergism among productivity shocks) and potential zero/infinite prices (which thus implies singularity of the

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In contrast, the invariance of input-output coefficients with respect to changes in quantitative magnitude under the setting specified above is known as the non-substitution theorem (see, e.g., Koopmans, 1951).
    ${ }^{2}$ Klein (1952) showed that, while the physical input-output coefficients will be affected by the economywide propagation of sectoral productivity shocks, the monetary input-output coefficients will not change because of the substitution elasticity of Cobb-Douglas technology which is neutral (i.e., unitary).

input-output linkages) can never be encountered under production networks base on CobbDouglas technology, where the monetary input-output linkages are stable. In this study we hence explore the role of substitution elasticities in regard to the emergence of network singularity and synergism in nonlinear Domar aggregation. ${ }^{3}$ In so doing, we work on CES production networks with a universal substitution elasticity $\sigma$, where the system of unit cost functions becomes linear with respect to the transcendent variables, i.e., variables transformed by the power of $(1-\sigma)$ th order. The final assessment of commodity prices by the representative household, nonetheless, remains as Cobb-Douglas, for simplicity.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the following section we present the benchmark general equilibrium system of equations encompassing multifactor CES unit cost functions with single (universal) substitution elasticity, and derive the Domar aggregation function with respect to the productivity shocks. The universal substitution elasticity setting with the use of transcendent variables allows us to handle general equilibrium solutions by means of linear algebra. In Section 3, we discuss network singularity and specify the conditions under which such situation can actually take place. We find that an inelastic (elastic) network may encounter a negative (positive) singularity. In Section 4, we discuss synergy in the economic evaluation of two different innovations. We find that an inelastic (elastic) network entails negative (positive) synergism. Section 5 concludes the paper.

# 2 The model
### 2.1 Household

Below are the representative household's utility function wich we assume as Cobb-Douglas, and the corresponding indirect utility function:

$$
U(\boldsymbol{c})=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(c_{i} / \kappa_{i}\right)^{\kappa_{i}}, \quad V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))=B \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(p_{i}\right)^{-\kappa_{i}}
$$

where, $n$ denotes the size of variety of commodities, $\boldsymbol{c}=\left(c_{1}, \cdots, c_{n}\right)$ denotes the consumption schedule, $\boldsymbol{p}=\left(p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}\right)$ denotes the price of commodities, and $B$ denotes the representative household's (or national) income, which equals the total value added or the nominal GDP. The share parameter for the $i$ th item is denoted by $\kappa_{i}$ where $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \kappa_{i}=1$. The equivalence of the two functions is shown in Appendix A. The price index in this case is described as $I(\boldsymbol{p})=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(p_{i}\right)^{\kappa_{i}}$. The representative household's indirect utility $V$ can then be referred to as the aggregate output (or, real GDP). Since we fix the amount of labor force $L$ and the wage rate $p_{0}$, the national income $B=p_{0} L$, or the nominal GDP, stays constant. The real GDP, on the other hand, will change as the price index $I(\boldsymbol{p})$ changes. Thus, if we normalize the price of commodities at the reference state by unity, the aggregate output growth will be evaluated as follows:

$$
\log V=-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \kappa_{i} \log p_{i}=-(\log \boldsymbol{p}) \boldsymbol{\kappa}
$$

where $\log \boldsymbol{p}=\left(\log p_{1}, \cdots, \log p_{n}\right)$, and $\boldsymbol{\kappa}=\left(\kappa_{1}, \cdots, \kappa_{n}\right)^{\top}$ denotes the column vector of expenditure share parameters.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ The singularity of the input-output structure and its association with infinite/zero prices are studied in Hawkins and Simon (1949) and Kurz and Salvadori (1994) from different perspectives.

# 2.2 Production 

We write below a CES production of constant returns to scale and the corresponding unit cost function for the $j$ th industry (index suppressed), with $i=1, \cdots, n$ being an intermediate factor input and $i=0$ being a single primary factor of production (see, Appendix B).

$$
F(\boldsymbol{x} ; z)=z\left(\sum_{i=0}^{n}\left(\alpha_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{\sigma}}\left(x_{i}\right)^{\frac{x-1}{\sigma}}\right)^{\frac{\sigma}{\sigma-1}}, \quad C(\boldsymbol{p} ; z)=z^{-1}\left(\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right)^{\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}
$$

Here, the elasticity of substitution is denoted by $\sigma$. The share parameter for the $i$ th item is denoted by $\alpha_{i}$, and it is assumed that $\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}=1$. The quantities for factor inputs are denoted by $\boldsymbol{x}=\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)$. The primary factor is designated as the numéraire and its price is set to unity, i.e., $p_{0}=1$. The Hickes-neutral productivity level of the sector is denoted by $z>0$.

The competitive environment under the constancy in returns to scale will lead to zero profit, i.e., $p=C(\boldsymbol{p} ; z)$, where $p$ denotes the selling price of the commodity produced. Under the nonneutral assumption, i.e., $\sigma \neq 1$, the zero profit condition implies,

$$
p^{1-\sigma}=z^{\sigma-1} \sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma}
$$

which is linear in terms of the transcendent variables as follows:

$$
\pi=\zeta\left(\alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1} \pi_{1}+\cdots+\alpha_{n} \pi_{n}\right)
$$

Here, the transcendent variables are: $\pi=p^{1-\sigma}$, and $\zeta=z^{\sigma-1}$. Note that if the elasticity of substitution is neutral, i.e., $\sigma=1$, the zero profit condition becomes linear in the logarithmic variables (see, Appendix C), as follows:

$$
\log p=-(\log z)+\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i} \log p_{i}
$$

As we assume universal elasticity of substitution common to all production sectors, equation (4) will stand for all $j=1, \cdots, n$ production sectors. We may therefore describe the general equilibrium system of equations as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{11}\left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 1}\left(\pi_{n}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right) \\
& \left(p_{2}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\left(z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12}\left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 2}\left(\pi_{n}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right) \\
& \quad \vdots \\
& \left(p_{n}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\left(z_{n}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\alpha_{0 n}+\alpha_{1 n}\left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}+\cdots+\alpha_{n n}\left(\pi_{n}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

or, more concisely, in terms of the transcendent variables, as follows:

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle+\boldsymbol{\pi}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}
$$

where row vectors $\boldsymbol{\zeta}=\left(\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1}, \cdots,\left(z_{n}\right)^{\sigma-1}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{\pi}=\left(\left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}, \cdots,\left(p_{n}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right)$ respectively denote sectoral productivity shocks and commodity prices, both in transcendent

mode. Angle brackets indicate vector diagonalization. The cost share parameters for nonprimary factors are denoted by the matrix $\mathbf{A}=\left[\alpha_{i j}\right]$, whereas those for the primary factor are denoted by a row vector $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}=\left(\alpha_{01}, \cdots, \alpha_{0 n}\right)$.

The equilibrium solution for (7) can be solved algebraically as follows:

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle[\mathbf{I}-\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}]^{-1}
$$

Since $\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i j}=1$ for all $j=1, \cdots, n$, or equivalently, $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}+\mathbf{1 A}=\mathbf{1}$, we know that the price of all commodities are unity at the reference state (where $\boldsymbol{z}=\left(z_{1}, \cdots, z_{n}\right)=$ $(1, \cdots, 1)=\mathbf{1})$, as follows:

$$
\mathbf{1}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}]^{-1}
$$

Also note that the cost share parameter equals the cost share of the reference state (see Appendix B).

Alternatively, If all the sectors produce commodities via neutral elasticity of substitution, equation (5) will stand for all $j=1, \cdots, n$ production sectors. We may then describe the general equilibrium system of equations, in terms of the logarithmic variables, as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log p_{1} & =-\log z_{1}+\alpha_{11} \log p_{1}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 1} \log p_{n} \\
\log p_{2} & =-\log z_{2}+\alpha_{12} \log p_{1}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 2} \log p_{n} \\
& \vdots \\
\log p_{n} & =-\log z_{n}+\alpha_{1 n} \log p_{1}+\cdots+\alpha_{n n} \log p_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

The equilibrium solution for (10) can be solved as follows:

$$
\log \boldsymbol{p}=-(\log \boldsymbol{z})[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}]^{-1}
$$

where $\log \boldsymbol{z}=\left(\log z_{1}, \cdots, \log z_{n}\right)$.

# 2.3 Network transformation 

In this study, the monetary input-output coefficient matrix is reffered to as the production network. A sector's monetary input-output coefficient for the $i$ th factor is its cost-share of the $i$ th factor. By applying Shephard's lemma to CES unit cost function of the $j$ th sector, and together with zero profit condition, cost-share for the $i$ th factor, which we denote by $s_{i j}$, can be evaluated as follows:

$$
s_{i j}=\alpha_{i j}\left(\frac{p_{i}}{z_{j} p_{j}}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\alpha_{i j} \zeta_{j} \frac{\pi_{i}}{\pi_{j}}
$$

Here, $\pi_{i}=\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma}$ and $\pi_{j}=\left(p_{j}\right)^{1-\sigma}$ are solutions to the general equilibrium system of equations (7) that must only depend on the sectoral productivity levels $\boldsymbol{z}=\left(z_{1}, \cdots, z_{n}\right)$. We know, by virtue of (8), that $s_{i j}=\alpha_{i j}$ at the reference state, since it is $\mathbf{1}=\boldsymbol{z}=\boldsymbol{\zeta}$ and hence, $\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{p}=\mathbf{1}$. Conversely, productivity shocks, i.e., $\boldsymbol{z} \neq \mathbf{1}$ will transform the production network, i.e., $s_{i j} \neq \alpha_{i j}$, only if the elasticity of substitution is nonneutral, i.e., $\sigma \neq 1$. Note, if the elasticity of substitution is neutral, i.e., $\sigma=1$, it is always the case that $s_{i j}=\alpha_{i j}$, that is, the production network is invariable regardless of the productivity shocks and associated changes in prices.

For later convenience, let us call a production network subject to substitution elasticity less than unity $(\sigma<1)$, an inelastic network, and that subject to substitution elasticity greater than unity $(\sigma>1)$, an elastic network. A neutroelastic network $(\sigma=1)$ is otherwise called a Cobb-Douglas production network. Both inelastic and elastic networks are subject to transformation given sectoral productivity shocks, whereas neutroelastic network is not.

# 2.4 Domar aggregation 

As mentioned earlier, Domar aggregation is a function that maps the set of sectoral productivity shocks (in terms of growths), i.e., $\log \boldsymbol{z}=\left(\log z_{1}, \cdots, \log z_{n}\right)$, onto the aggregate economic growth, i.e., $\log V$. If all sectoral productions universally entail neutral substitution elasticity, i.e., $\sigma=1$, the Domar aggregation (under Cobb-Douglas utility) can be described, by virtue of equations (2) and (11), as follows:

$$
\log V=(\log z)[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}]^{-1} \boldsymbol{\kappa} \quad(\sigma=1)
$$

Otherwise, if all sectoral productions universally entail a single nonneutral substitution elasticity, i.e., $\sigma \neq 1$, the Domar aggregation (under Cobb-Douglas utility) can be described, by virtue of equations (2) and (8), as follows:

$$
\log V=\frac{1}{\sigma-1} \log \left(\left[\mathbf{I}-\left\langle e^{(\sigma-1) \log \boldsymbol{z}}\right\rangle \mathbf{A}\right]^{-1}\left\langle e^{(\sigma-1) \log \boldsymbol{z}}\right\rangle \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}\right) \boldsymbol{\kappa} \quad(\sigma \neq 1)
$$

Formula (12) indicates that Domar aggregation is linear as long as the elasticity of substitution across the production network is neutral. Note that the column vector $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}]^{-1} \boldsymbol{\kappa}$ corresponds to the Domar weights. The linearity stems from the robustness of the production network against sectoral productivity shocks under neutral substitution elasticity. In contrast, formula (13) indicates that Domar aggregation is nonlinear if the elasticity of substitution across the production network is nonneutral. The nonlinearity stems from the fragility of the production network against sectoral productivity shocks under nonneutral substitution elasticity. Fallacy of composition (or, synergism) will never take place for linear Domar aggregation that does not evoke network transformation, whereas it will take place for nonlinear Domar aggregation that brings about network transfromation.

## 3 Singularities
### 3.1 Two-sector model

Consider a two-sector general equilibrium system where commodity prices are determined by CES unit cost functions with universal substitution elasticity $\sigma$, as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{21}\left(p_{2}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right) \\
& \left(p_{2}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\left(z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12}\left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For sake of simplicity, we assume no self-inputs, i.e., $\alpha_{11}=\alpha_{22}=0$. The transcendental general equilibrium system of equations can be solved in terms of the transcendant variables

via (8), as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] } & =\left[\alpha_{01}, \alpha_{02}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\zeta_{1} & 0 \\
0 & \zeta_{2}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}
{[10]} \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\zeta_{1} & 0 \\
0 & \zeta_{2}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0 & \alpha_{12} \\
\alpha_{21} & 0
\end{array}\right]\right]^{-1} \\
& =\frac{1}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \zeta_{1} \zeta_{2}}\left[\alpha_{01} \zeta_{1}+\alpha_{21} \zeta_{1} \alpha_{02} \zeta_{2}, \alpha_{02} \zeta_{2}+\alpha_{12} \zeta_{2} \alpha_{01} \zeta_{1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The general equilibrium price can hence be solved as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(p_{1}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\frac{\alpha_{01}\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1}+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02}\left(z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12}\left(z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}} \\
& \left(p_{2}\right)^{1-\sigma}=\frac{\alpha_{02}\left(z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01}\left(z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12}\left(z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $\sigma>0$ (where the elasticity of substitution cannot take negative values), and for any $\boldsymbol{z}>0$ (where the productivity levels cannot take negative values), it must be the case that $\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{p}^{1-\sigma}>0$, i.e., the equilibrium price either in normal or transcendent form must take nonnegative values. In other words, the following nonsingularity condition (for the transcendent network) must hold.

$$
D=1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12}\left(z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}>0
$$

Note that (16) is equivalent to the condition under which the transcendental general equilibrium system of equations has a nonnegative solution, i.e., $[\mathbf{I}-\langle\zeta\rangle \mathbf{A}]^{-1}\langle\zeta\rangle \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}>0$ for any $\langle\zeta\rangle \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}>0$, which can be specified, with regard to Hawkins and Simon (1949); Takayama (1985), as follows:

$$
D=\operatorname{det}(\mathbf{I}-\langle\zeta\rangle \mathbf{A})=1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \zeta_{1} \zeta_{2}>0
$$

Figure 1 depicts sample contour plots of the determinant $D$ with respect to sectoral productivity shocks $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)$, according to (16). The figure shows that some simultaneous productivity decrease, such that $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)<(1,1)$, for an inelastic network, or, some simultaneous productivity increase, such that $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)>(1,1)$, for an elastic network, can either make the transcendent network singular. Singularity of the transcendent network, i.e., $D \rightarrow 0$ indicates transcendent prices approach infinity, i.e., $\boldsymbol{\pi} \rightarrow \infty$. As regards the normal prices are concerned, this implies the following:

$$
\boldsymbol{p}=\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\frac{1}{1-\sigma}} \rightarrow \begin{cases}\infty & (\sigma<1, \boldsymbol{z}<\mathbf{1}) \\ 0 & (\sigma>1, \boldsymbol{z}>\mathbf{1})\end{cases}
$$

That is to say, commodity price can get infinitely large by some finite productivity decline for an inelastic network, whereas commodity price can approach zero by some finite productivity increase for an elastic network.

Let us look into the physical input-output coefficients $\boldsymbol{m}_{0}=\left(m_{01}, m_{02}\right)$ for labor, under singularity. Application of Shephard's lemma leads to the following, according to (37).

$$
m_{0 j}=\frac{x_{0 j}}{x_{j}}=\alpha_{0 j}\left(z_{j}\right)^{\sigma-1}\left(\frac{p_{j}}{p_{0}}\right)^{\sigma} \quad j=1,2
$$

Then for any kind of sectoral productivity shock $z_{j}>0$, since $p_{0}=1$, labor will be used indefinitely $\left(m_{0 j} \rightarrow \infty\right)$, if price of the commodity becomes infinitely high $\left(p_{j} \rightarrow \infty\right)$,

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Fig. 1: Contour plots of (16), where the horizontal and vertical axes correspond to $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$, respectively. The left figure corresponds to an inelastic network $\left(\sigma=0.9, \alpha_{21} \alpha_{12}=0.8\right)$, and the right figure to an elastic network $\left(\sigma=1.5, \alpha_{21} \alpha_{12}=0.6\right)$. The dotted line indicates singularity i.e., $D=0$. The dark areas are where $D<0$. Nonsingularity $(D>0)$ is held at the state of reference, i.e., $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=(1,1)$, for both cases.
while very little labor will be used $\left(m_{0 j} \rightarrow 0\right)$, if price of commodity nears zero $\left(p_{j} \rightarrow 0\right)$. The findings are summarized as follows:

$$
m_{0} \rightarrow \begin{cases}\infty & (p \rightarrow \infty) \\ 0 & (p \rightarrow 0)\end{cases}
$$

With (18) and (19) combined, we see that, 1) some productivity decline $(\boldsymbol{z} \leq \mathbf{1})$ under inelastic network $(\sigma<1)$ can create a situation where an immense amount of labor is needed to offset other factors of production $\left(\boldsymbol{m}_{0} \rightarrow \infty\right)$, and 2 ) some productivity increase $(\boldsymbol{z} \geq \mathbf{1})$ under elastic network $(\sigma>1)$ can create a situation where only the smallest amount of labor is needed to offset other factors of production $\left(\boldsymbol{m}_{0} \rightarrow 0\right)$. We hereafter refer to 1 ) as negative singularity and 2 ) as positive singularity. It must, however, be important to note that these singularities stem from the unlimited possibility of factor substitution installed in the isoquant of CES production function.

# 3.2 Multisector model 

The purpose of this section is to study whether if the transcendent network $\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$ turns out to be viable. In the former part of this section we show the viability of the reference network $\mathbf{A}$ and its equivalence to $\mathbf{A}^{\infty}=0$, and in the latter part we discuss the viability of the transcendent network $\langle\zeta\rangle \mathbf{A}$ in reference to $(\langle\zeta\rangle \mathbf{A})^{\infty} .{ }^{4}$ To study the matter formally, let us first define network viability, as follows:

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ Hawkins and Simon (1949)'s approach to examine the viability of the network $\mathbf{W}$, is to see whether if all the successive principal minor determinants of $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}$ are positive, which is exactly the one we took for the two-sector case in (17). For the multisector case we take an alternative approach of Nikaido (1968)'s.

Definition (Column viability). A network, i.e., $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{W}$, is said to be column viable, if for any column vector $\mathbf{f}>0$, there exists a column vector $\mathbf{y}>0$ such that $\mathbf{y}=\mathbf{f}+\mathbf{W y}$.
Definition (Row viability). A network, i.e., $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{W}$, is said to be row viable, if for any row vector $\mathbf{v}>0$, there exists a row vector $\mathbf{q}>0$ such that $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{v}+\mathbf{q W}$.

Assumption. The reference network $\mathbf{A}$ is nondefective, meaning all $n$ nonzero eigenvalues are distinct, thus diagonalizable.

By virtue of Lemmas 3, 4, 5, and 6, which we append to Appendix D with proofs, we know that reference network $\mathbf{A}$ is row (and also column) viable and that $\mathbf{A}^{\infty}=0$. Moreover, by virtue of the above Assumption, $\mathbf{A}$ is diagonalizable as follows:

$$
\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{Q}\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1}>0
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \cdots, \lambda_{n}\right)$ denotes the set of $n$ nonzero eigenvalues and $\mathbf{Q}$ is some invertable matrix. Since $\mathbf{A}^{\infty}=\mathbf{Q}\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle^{\infty} \mathbf{Q}^{-1}$, and hence, $\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle^{\infty}=\mathbf{Q}^{-1} \mathbf{A}^{\infty} \mathbf{Q}=0$, we know that

$$
\left|\lambda_{i}\right|<1 \quad i=1, \cdots, n
$$

By Lemma 6, we know the transcendent network $\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$ will be row viable, i.e., for any row vector $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle>0$, there exists a row vector $\boldsymbol{\pi}>0$ such that $\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle+\boldsymbol{\pi}\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$, or the solution to equation (7) exists, while $[\mathbf{I}-\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}]$ is invertable, as long as $\left(\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}\right)^{\infty}=0$. By virtue of (20), the transcendent network can be evaluated as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}=\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{Q}\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1} & <\zeta_{\max } \mathbf{Q}\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1}=\mathbf{Q}\left\langle\zeta_{\max } \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1} \\
& >\zeta_{\min } \mathbf{Q}\langle\boldsymbol{\lambda}\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1}=\mathbf{Q}\left\langle\zeta_{\min } \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right\rangle \mathbf{Q}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\zeta_{\max }=\operatorname{argmax}\left(\zeta_{1}, \cdots, \zeta_{n}\right)$ and $\zeta_{\min }=\operatorname{argmin}\left(\zeta_{1}, \cdots, \zeta_{n}\right)$. Therefore,

$$
\left\langle\zeta_{\max } \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right\rangle^{\infty}>\mathbf{Q}^{-1}\left(\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}\right)^{\infty} \mathbf{Q}>\left\langle\zeta_{\min } \boldsymbol{\lambda}\right\rangle^{\infty}>0
$$

By virtue of (21) and (22) we arrive at the following lemmas:
Lemma 1 Row viability of $\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$ is secured if $\zeta_{\max }<1 /\left|\lambda_{i}\right|>1$ for all $i=1, \cdots, n$.
Lemma 2 Row viability of $\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$ is violated if $\zeta_{\min }>1 /\left|\lambda_{i}\right|>1$ for all $i=1, \cdots, n$.
Note that violation of row viability (for a network such that $\mathbf{W}^{\infty}=\infty$ ) implies:

$$
\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{v}+\mathbf{q} \mathbf{W}=\mathbf{v}\left(\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{W}+\mathbf{W}^{2}+\cdots+\mathbf{W}^{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \infty
$$

Thus, violation of row viability for $\langle\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle \mathbf{A}$ implies $\boldsymbol{\pi}=\boldsymbol{p}^{1-\sigma} \rightarrow \infty$, or transcendent network singularity, and by Lemma 2, this occurs if $\zeta_{\min }=\hat{z}^{\sigma-1}>1$, but by Lemma 1 , this will never occur if $\zeta_{\max }=\hat{z}^{\sigma-1}<1$. Note that $\hat{z}<1$ and $\hat{z}>1$ if $\sigma<1$, whereas $\hat{z}>1$ and $\hat{z}<1$ if $\sigma>1$. Moreover, $\boldsymbol{p}^{1-\sigma}=\infty$ implies $\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow \infty$ if $\sigma<1$, whereas $\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow 0$ if $\sigma>1$. We now can summarize the results obtained thus far below:

Proposition 1 (Negative singularity). Under an inelastic network ( $\sigma<1$ ), any productivity increase $(\boldsymbol{z}>1)$ will lead to finite commodity price $(\boldsymbol{p} \ll \infty)$, whereas some productivity decrease $(\boldsymbol{z}<1)$ can lead to infinite commodity price $(\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow \infty)$.
Proposition 2 (Positive singularity). Under an elastic network ( $\sigma>1$ ), any productivity decrease $(\boldsymbol{z}<1)$ will lead to finite commodity price $(\boldsymbol{p} \ll \infty)$, whereas some productivity increase $(\boldsymbol{z}>1)$ can lead to zero commodity price $(\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow 0)$.

# 4 Synergism
### 4.1 Two-sector model

Consider the previous two-sector model (14) redisplayed below in transcendent mode:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}=\delta\left(\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{21} \pi_{2}\right) \\
& \pi_{2}=\varepsilon\left(\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \pi_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we use $(\delta, \varepsilon)$ instead of $\left(\zeta_{1}, \zeta_{2}\right)$ for convenience. Hereafter, we denote the equilibrium solution as a function of exogenous variables, i.e., $\left(\pi_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon), \pi_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon)\right)$. All prices are standardized (set to unity) at the reference state $(\delta, \varepsilon)=(1,1)$, i.e., $\left(\pi_{1}(1,1), \pi_{2}(1,1)\right)=$ $(1,1)$. Moreover, we consider transcendental productivity changes in the same direction, i.e., $(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless(1,1)$, which correspond to (natural) productivity changes in the same direction, depending on the universal elasticity of substitution $\sigma$, as follows:

$$
(\delta, \varepsilon)=\left(\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1},\left(z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}\right) \gtrless(1,1) \Longleftrightarrow \begin{cases}\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right) \lessgarrow(1,1) & 1-\sigma>0 \\ \left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right) \gtrless(1,1) & 1-\sigma<0\end{cases}
$$

By virtue of (15), the following expositions are obvious:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\pi_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon), \pi_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon)\right)=\left(\frac{\alpha_{01} \delta+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \delta \varepsilon}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta \varepsilon}, \frac{\alpha_{02} \varepsilon+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \delta \varepsilon}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta \varepsilon}\right) \\
& \left(\pi_{1}(\delta, 1), \pi_{2}(\delta, 1)\right)=\left(\frac{\alpha_{01} \delta+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \delta}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta}, \frac{\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \delta}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta}\right) \\
& \left(\pi_{1}(1, \varepsilon), \pi_{2}(1, \varepsilon)\right)=\left(\frac{\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \varepsilon}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \varepsilon}, \frac{\alpha_{02} \varepsilon+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \varepsilon}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \varepsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

After some calculations, we can show the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon)-\pi_{1}(\delta, 1) \pi_{1}(1, \varepsilon)=\frac{(1-\delta)(1-\varepsilon)\left(\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{02} \varepsilon\right) \alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta}{\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta \varepsilon\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \varepsilon\right)} \\
& \pi_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon)-\pi_{2}(\delta, 1) \pi_{2}(1, \varepsilon)=\frac{(1-\delta)(1-\varepsilon)\left(\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{01} \delta\right) \alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \varepsilon}{\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta \varepsilon\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \varepsilon\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

For both equations, the right hand sides are positive as long as the productivities change in the same direction, i.e., $(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless(1,1)$ as we assume so henceforth. Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\pi_{1}(\delta, 1), \pi_{2}(\delta, 1)\right) & =\left(\frac{\alpha_{01} \delta+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \delta}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta}, \frac{\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \delta}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta}\right) \\
\left(\pi_{1}\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right), \pi_{2}\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)\right) & =\left(\frac{\alpha_{01} \delta^{\prime}+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \delta^{\prime}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta^{\prime}}, \frac{\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \delta^{\prime}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta^{\prime}}\right) \\
\left(\pi_{1}\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, 1\right), \pi_{2}\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, 1\right)\right) & =\left(\frac{\alpha_{01} \delta \delta^{\prime}+\alpha_{21} \alpha_{02} \delta \delta^{\prime}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta \delta^{\prime}}, \frac{\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \alpha_{01} \delta \delta^{\prime}}{1-\alpha_{21} \alpha_{12} \delta \delta^{\prime}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

After some calculations, we can show the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, 1\right)-\pi_{1}(\delta, 1) \pi_{1}\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)=\frac{(1-\delta)\left(1-\delta^{\prime}\right) \delta \delta^{\prime}\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21}\right) \alpha_{12} \alpha_{21}}{\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta \delta^{\prime}\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta^{\prime}\right)} \\
& \pi_{2}\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, 1\right)-\pi_{2}(\delta, 1) \pi_{2}\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)=\frac{(1-\delta)\left(1-\delta^{\prime}\right)\left(\alpha_{02}+\delta \delta^{\prime} \alpha_{01} \alpha_{21}\left(\alpha_{12}\right)^{2}\right) \alpha_{12}}{\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta \delta^{\prime}\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta\right)\left(1-\alpha_{12} \alpha_{21} \delta^{\prime}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The right hand sides are both positive as long as $\left(\delta, \delta^{\prime}\right) \gtrless(1,1)$.
In any case,

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\pi_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon)>\pi_{1}(\delta, 1) \pi_{1}(1, \varepsilon) & \Longleftrightarrow & \left(p_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon)\right)^{1-\sigma}>\left(p_{1}(\delta, 1) p_{1}(1, \varepsilon)\right)^{1-\sigma} \\
\pi_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon)>\pi_{2}(\delta, 1) \pi_{2}(1, \varepsilon) & \Longleftrightarrow & \left(p_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon)\right)^{1-\sigma}>\left(p_{2}(\delta, 1) p_{2}(1, \varepsilon)\right)^{1-\sigma}
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, in regard to (25), for any $(\delta, \varepsilon)=\left(\left(z_{1}\right)^{\sigma-1},\left(z_{2}\right)^{\sigma-1}\right) \gtrless(1,1)$, the price changes are evaluated, depending on the universal elasticity of substitution, as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log p_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless \log p_{1}(\delta, 1)+\log p_{1}(1, \varepsilon) \\
& \log p_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless \log p_{2}(\delta, 1)+\log p_{2}(1, \varepsilon)
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, the aggregate growths are evaluated as follows:

$$
\log V(\delta, \varepsilon) \lessgtr \log V(\delta, 1)+\log V(1, \varepsilon) \quad 1-\sigma \gtrless 0
$$

by applying (2), or specifically the followings:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log V(\delta, \varepsilon)=-\kappa_{1} \log p_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon)-\kappa_{2} \log p_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon) \\
& \log V(\delta, 1)=-\kappa_{1} \log p_{1}(\delta, 1)-\kappa_{2} \log p_{2}(\delta, 1) \\
& \log V(1, \varepsilon)=-\kappa_{1} \log p_{1}(1, \varepsilon)-\kappa_{2} \log p_{2}(1, \varepsilon)
\end{aligned}
$$

Below we summarize the results obtained so far, concerning (27) with regard to (24):
Proposition 3 (Negative sinergism). Under an inelastic network ( $\sigma<1$ ), the aggregate output pertaining to simultaneous productivity increases (or decreases), i.e., $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right) \gtrless(1,1)$, is less than the sum of aggregate outputs that pertain to individual productivity increases (or decreases), i.e., $\left(z_{1} \gtrless 1, z_{2}=1\right)$ and $\left(z_{1}=1, z_{2} \gtrless 1\right)$.
Proposition 4 (Positive sinergism). Under an elastic network ( $\sigma>1$ ), the aggregate output pertaining to simultaneous productivity increases (or decreases), i.e., $\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right) \gtrless(1,1)$, is greater than the sum of aggregate outputs that pertain to individual productivity increases (or decreases), i.e., $\left(z_{1} \gtrless 1, z_{2}=1\right)$ and $\left(z_{1}=1, z_{2} \gtrless 1\right)$.

# 4.2 Multisector model 

Below is the multisector model (6) redisplayed in transcendent mode:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}=\delta\left(\alpha_{01}+\alpha_{11} \pi_{1}+\alpha_{21} \pi_{2}+\alpha_{31} \pi_{3}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 1} \pi_{n}\right) \\
& \pi_{2}=\varepsilon\left(\alpha_{02}+\alpha_{12} \pi_{1}+\alpha_{22} \pi_{2}+\alpha_{32} \pi_{3}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 2} \pi_{n}\right) \\
& \pi_{3}=1\left(\alpha_{03}+\alpha_{13} \pi_{1}+\alpha_{23} \pi_{2}+\alpha_{33} \pi_{3}+\cdots+\alpha_{n 3} \pi_{n}\right) \\
& \vdots \\
& \pi_{n}=1\left(\alpha_{0 n}+\alpha_{1 n} \pi_{1}+\alpha_{2 n} \pi_{2}+\alpha_{3 n} \pi_{3}+\cdots+\alpha_{n n} \pi_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where, productivity changes are assumed to occur exclusively in the first and the second sectors. With obvious notational correspondence, we can rewrite the above system of equations more concisely as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{1} & =\delta\left(\alpha_{01}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 1}+\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r} \mathbf{A}_{r 1}\right) \\
\pi_{2} & =\varepsilon\left(\alpha_{02}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 2}+\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r} \mathbf{A}_{r 2}\right) \\
\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r} & =\mathbf{I}\left(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0 r}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) r}+\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r} \mathbf{A}_{r r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 1}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 2}$ are $2 \times 1$ column vectors, $\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r}$ and $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0 r}$ are $1 \times(n-2)$ row vectors. $\mathbf{A}_{r 1}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{r 2}$ are $(n-2) \times 1$ column vectors, $\mathbf{A}_{(1,2) r}$ is a $2 \times(n-2)$ matrix, and $\mathbf{A}_{r r}$ is an $(n-2) \times(n-2)$ matrix. Notice the system of equations (31) can be solved as follows:

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}_{r}=\left(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0 r}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) r}\right)\left[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}_{r r}\right]^{-1}
$$

Plugging (32) into (29) and (30) yields the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}=\delta\left(\alpha_{01}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 1}+\left(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0 r}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) r}\right)\left[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}_{r r}\right]^{-1} \mathbf{A}_{r 1}\right) \\
& \pi_{2}=\varepsilon\left(\alpha_{02}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) 2}+\left(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{0 r}+\left[\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}\right] \mathbf{A}_{(1,2) r}\right)\left[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}_{r r}\right]^{-1} \mathbf{A}_{r 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

With obvious notational correspondence, the system of equations (28) can be aggregated into a two-sector system of equations equivalent to (23), as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{1}=\delta\left(\hat{\alpha}_{01}+\hat{\alpha}_{11} \pi_{1}+\hat{\alpha}_{21} \pi_{2}\right)=\delta\left(\hat{\alpha}_{01}+\hat{\alpha}_{21} \pi_{2}\right) \\
& \pi_{2}=\varepsilon\left(\hat{\alpha}_{02}+\hat{\alpha}_{12} \pi_{1}+\hat{\alpha}_{22} \pi_{2}\right)=\varepsilon\left(\hat{\alpha}_{02}+\hat{\alpha}_{12} \pi_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, for the two sectors $k=1,2$, we know from (25) that for any $(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless(1,1)$,

$$
\log \pi_{k}(\delta, \varepsilon) \geq \log \pi_{k}(\delta, 1)+\log \pi_{k}(1, \varepsilon)
$$

As for the remaining sectors $r=3, \cdots, n$, we redisplay one entry of (32) below, with obvious notational correspondence:

$$
\pi_{r}=\hat{\alpha}_{0 r}+\hat{\alpha}_{1 r} \pi_{1}+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r} \pi_{2}
$$

To proceed further, we make an assumption that transcendental productivity growths are both infinitesimal, i.e., $(\log \delta, \log \varepsilon) \approx(0,0)$, so that $\pi_{i}(\delta, \varepsilon) \approx 1$ for all $i=1, \cdots, n$. The assumption then allows us to apply $\pi \approx 1+\log \pi$ for (34), as follows:

$$
1+\log \pi_{r}=\hat{\alpha}_{0 r}+\hat{\alpha}_{1 r}\left(1+\log \pi_{1}\right)+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r}\left(1+\log \pi_{2}\right)
$$

But because $\hat{\alpha}_{0 r}+\hat{\alpha}_{1 r}+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r}=1$, this reduces to the following:

$$
\log \pi_{r}=\hat{\alpha}_{1 r} \log \pi_{1}+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r} \log \pi_{2}
$$

By virtue of (33) and (35), we obtain the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \pi_{r}(\delta, \varepsilon) & =\hat{\alpha}_{1 r} \log \pi_{1}(\delta, \varepsilon)+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r} \log \pi_{2}(\delta, \varepsilon) \\
& >\hat{\alpha}_{1 r}\left(\log \pi_{1}(\delta, 1)+\log \pi_{1}(1, \varepsilon)\right)+\hat{\alpha}_{2 r}\left(\log \pi_{2}(\delta, 1)+\log \pi_{2}(1, \varepsilon)\right) \\
& =\log \pi_{r}(\delta, 1)+\log \pi_{r}(1, \varepsilon)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for any $(\log \delta, \log \varepsilon) \gtrless(0,0)$ that is infinitesimal, we know from (33) and (36) that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log \boldsymbol{\pi}(\delta, \varepsilon)>\log \boldsymbol{\pi}(\delta, 1)+\log \boldsymbol{\pi}(1, \varepsilon) \\
& \log \boldsymbol{p}(\delta, \varepsilon) \gtrless \log \boldsymbol{p}(\delta, 1)+\log \boldsymbol{p}(1, \varepsilon) \quad 1-\sigma \gtrless 0
\end{aligned}
$$

By applying (2), the presence of synergisms as noted in Propositions 3 and 4 are obvious as we derive the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log V(\delta, \varepsilon) & =-(\log \boldsymbol{p}(\delta, \varepsilon)) \boldsymbol{\kappa} \\
& \lessgtr-(\log \boldsymbol{p}(\delta, 1)) \boldsymbol{\kappa}-(\log \boldsymbol{p}(1, \varepsilon)) \boldsymbol{\kappa} \\
& =\log V(\delta, 1)+\log V(1, \varepsilon) \quad 1-\sigma \gtrless 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally we relax the infinitesimal assumption by showing that integration is possible. By utilizing not only (25) but also (26), we derive the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \pi\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, \varepsilon \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) & >\log \pi\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, \varepsilon\right)+\log \pi\left(\delta, \varepsilon \varepsilon^{\prime}\right)>\log \pi\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, 1\right)+\log \pi\left(1, \varepsilon \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) \\
& >\log \pi(\delta, 1)+\log \pi\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)+\log \pi(1, \varepsilon)+\log \pi\left(1, \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) \\
\log \boldsymbol{p}\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, \varepsilon \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) & \gtrless \log \boldsymbol{p}(\delta, 1)+\log \boldsymbol{p}\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)+\log \boldsymbol{p}(1, \varepsilon)+\log \boldsymbol{p}\left(1, \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) \quad 1-\sigma \gtrless 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\left(\delta^{\prime}, \varepsilon^{\prime}\right)$ are infinitesimal changes. By applying (2) we are left with the following result that allows us to integrate infinitesimal changes.

$$
\log V\left(\delta \delta^{\prime}, \varepsilon \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) \lessgtr \log V(\delta, 1)+\log V\left(\delta^{\prime}, 1\right)+\log V(1, \varepsilon)+\log V\left(1, \varepsilon^{\prime}\right) \quad 1-\sigma \gtrless 0
$$

# 5 Concluding Remarks 

According to Eden et al (2012), singularity hypotheses refer to two distinct scenarios. One is the intelligence explosion (Good, 1966), whereby machine intelligence surpasses human intelligence through computational advancement, which entails recursive self-improvement. The other scenario is the biointelligence explosion, which entails the amplification of human capabilities to overcome all existing human limitations (Kurzweil, 2005). In both ways, however, the concept of singularity (i.e., explosion) does not go beyond exponential growth, if not extreme. The economic singularity theory of Nordhaus (2021) also exploits the idea of extreme exponential growth of intelligence capital deepening by a large elasticity of substitution. In contrast, the singularity presented in this study is based on matrix singularity where the matrix is transformed by virtue of the substitution elasticity that is nonneutral.

Of course, positive singularity cannot take place unless some finite amount of non-labor commodity can completely substitute the primary factor of production. Our model allowed convergence towards positive singularity because our (standard) CES production function allowed production even at the extreme position of the isoquant near the axes. On the other hand, negative singularity is not an improbable event. With some productivity-diminishing innovations, such as those involving environmental conservation technologies, network transformation under inelastic network can encounter a state that some commodity cannot be produced in net. Finally, as regards the matter of industrial policy, whether to promote a portfolio of projects, or rather to take a selective policy, depends on the synergism inherent in the production network where the elasticity of substitution plays the important role.

## Appendix A (Cobb-Douglas indirect utility function)

By applying Roy's identity to the Cobb-Douglas indirect utility function (1 right), we obtain the following:

$$
-\frac{\partial V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))}{\partial p_{i}}=\left(\frac{\kappa_{i}}{p_{i}}\right) V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))=\frac{\partial V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))}{\partial B} c_{i}=\frac{V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))}{B} c_{i}
$$

By the equality between the second and the fourth terms, and the equality of income and expenditure, i.e., $B=\sum_{i=1}^{4} p_{i} c_{i}$, following conditions are taken for granted:

$$
\kappa_{i}=\frac{p_{i} c_{i}}{B} . \quad \sum_{i=1}^{n} \kappa_{i}=1
$$

By using the above, the equivalence between $U$ and $V$ is evident as follows.

$$
V(\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{p}, B))=B \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(p_{i}\right)^{-\kappa_{i}}=B \prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(B \kappa_{i} / c_{i}\right)^{-\kappa_{i}}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(c_{i} / \kappa_{i}\right)^{\kappa_{i}}=U(\boldsymbol{c})
$$

# Appendix B (CES production and cost functions) 

By applying Shephard's lemma to the CES unit cost function (3 right), we obtain the following:

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial p_{i}}=\alpha_{i} z^{\sigma-1}\left(\frac{p}{p_{i}}\right)^{\sigma}=\frac{x_{i}}{x}
$$

Note, at the reference state where $z=1$ and $p_{i}=1$ for all $i=0,1, \cdots, n$, we know from (37) that the share parameter equals the cost share, i.e., $\alpha_{i}=x_{i} / x=\left(p_{i} x_{i}\right) /(p x)$. Because the unit cost function is homogeneous of the first order in $p_{0}, p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}$, Euler's homogeneous function theorem applies whereby:

$$
p=\sum_{i=0}^{n}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial p_{i}}\right) p_{i}=\sum_{i=0}^{n} \frac{p_{i} x_{i}}{x}
$$

Combining (37) and (38) yields:

$$
x=\sum_{i=0}^{n}\left(\frac{p_{i}}{p}\right) x_{i}=\sum_{i=0}^{n}\left(\alpha_{i} x\right)^{\frac{1}{\sigma}}\left(z x_{i}\right)^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}}
$$

By arranging terms we have the CES production function $F(\boldsymbol{x} ; z)$ as follows:

$$
x^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}}=z^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}} \sum_{i=0}^{n}\left(\alpha_{i}\right)^{\frac{1}{\sigma}}\left(x_{i}\right)^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}}=(F(\boldsymbol{x} ; z))^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}}
$$

## Appendix C (Derivation of (5))

By taking the logarithm of $z C(\boldsymbol{p} ; z)$ and applying L'Hôpital's rule to let $\sigma \rightarrow 1$, we obtain the following:

$$
\log (z C(\boldsymbol{p} ; z))=\lim _{\sigma \rightarrow 1} \frac{\log \left(\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma}\right)}{1-\sigma}=\lim _{\sigma \rightarrow 1} \frac{\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma} \log p_{i}}{\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}\left(p_{i}\right)^{1-\sigma}}=\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i} \ln p_{i}
$$

where we used $\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i}=1$ for the last identity. With the zero profit condition, i.e., $p=C(\boldsymbol{p} ; z)$, we have the formula (5).

## Appendix D (Viability assessment of networks)

The following lemmas owe to Nikaido (1968), McKenzie (2009), and Takayama (1985).
Lemma 3 The reference Leontief matrix $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}$ is nonsingular.
Proof. Suppose that $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}$ is singular. Then, there is a column vector $\boldsymbol{x} \neq 0$ such that $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}] \boldsymbol{x}=0$. Consider the $i$ th equation of $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}] \boldsymbol{x}=0$ as follows,

$$
x_{i}-\alpha_{i 1} x_{1}-\alpha_{i 2} x_{2} \cdots-\alpha_{i k} x_{k} \cdots-\alpha_{i n} x_{n}=0
$$

Summing all $n$ equations gives the following:

$$
\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \alpha_{i 1}\right) x_{1}+\cdots+\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \alpha_{i n}\right) x_{n}=0
$$

Since, $\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i j}=1$ for all $j=1, \cdots, n$ where $\alpha_{i j}>0$, the terms inside the parentheses are all positive, therefore, $x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}$ cannot be all positive or all negative. By rearranging the order of elements, we may let $x_{1}, \cdots, x_{k}$ be negative, and $x_{k+1}, \cdots, x_{n}$ be positive. Summing the first $k$ equations on both sides gives:

$$
\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i 1}\right) x_{1}+\cdots+\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i k}\right) x_{k}-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \sum_{j=k+1}^{n} \alpha_{i j} x_{j}=0
$$

Since the terms inside the parentheses are all positive, the left hand side must be negative, which draws a contradiction with the right hand side. Hence $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}$ cannot be singular.

Lemma 4 The reference network (input-output coefficient matrix) $\mathbf{A}$ is column viable. ${ }^{5}$
Proof. Consider the $i$ th equation of $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}] \boldsymbol{x}=\mathbf{f}>0$ as follows,

$$
y_{i}-\alpha_{i 1} x_{1}-\alpha_{i 2} x_{2} \cdots-\alpha_{i k} x_{k} \cdots-\alpha_{i n} x_{n}=f_{i}>0
$$

Suppose that $x_{1}, \cdots, x_{k}$ are not all positive. By rearranging the order of elements, we may let $x_{1}, \cdots, x_{k}$ be negative, and $x_{k+1}, \cdots, x_{n}$ be positive. Summing the first $k$ equations on both sides gives:

$$
\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i 1}\right) x_{1}+\cdots+\left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \alpha_{i k}\right) x_{k}-\sum_{i=1}^{k} \sum_{j=k+1}^{n} \alpha_{i j} x_{j}=\sum_{i=1}^{k} f_{i}>0
$$

Since, $\sum_{i=0}^{n} \alpha_{i j}=1$ for all $j=1, \cdots, n$ where $\alpha_{i j}>0$, all the terms inside the parentheses are positive. Then, the left hand side must be negative, which draws a contradiction with the right hand side. Hence, $x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}$ must all be positive.

Lemma 5 If an $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{W}$ is column viable and $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}$ is nonsingular, then $\mathbf{W}$ is row viable and $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>0$.

Proof. Since $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}$ is nonsingular it has an inverse $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}$ where we denote each item by $\ell_{i j}$. Consider the $i$ th equation of $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1} \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{y}$, as follows.

$$
\ell_{i 1} f_{1}+\cdots+\ell_{i n} f_{n}=y_{i}
$$

Suppose if, by rearranging the order of elements, the first $k$ entries are negative, i.e., $\ell_{i j}<0$ for $j=1, \cdots, k$ and the rest are positive. By the column viability of $\mathbf{W}$, any nonnegative set $\left(f_{1}, \cdots, f_{n}\right)$ must make the left hand side positive. However, if we choose $f_{j}=1$ for $j=1, \cdots, k$ and $f_{j}=0$ for $j=k+1, \cdots, n$, the left hand side will be negative, which draws a contradiction with the right hand side that is postive. Thus, $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>0$, which then implies that for any row vector $\mathbf{v}>0, \mathbf{v}[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>0$, or the row viability of $\mathbf{W}$.

Lemma 6 An $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{W}>0$ is row viable and $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>0 . \Longleftrightarrow \mathbf{W}^{\infty}=0$.
Proof. Define $\mathbf{L}_{T}=\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{W}+\mathbf{W}^{2}+\cdots+\mathbf{W}^{T}$. Because $\mathbf{W}>0$, we know that $\mathbf{L}_{T}>0$ is monotonically increasing in $T$, and also that $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}] \mathbf{L}_{T}=\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}^{T+1}<\mathbf{I}$. We then see that $\mathbf{L}_{T}$ is bounded from above by the following exposition:

$$
[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>\mathbf{L}_{T}>\mathbf{L}_{T-1}>\cdots>\mathbf{L}_{0}
$$

Since $\mathbf{L}_{T}$ is bounded and monotonically increasing in $T$, we know that $\mathbf{L}_{\infty}$ is convergent. Hence, we arrive at the wanted result:

$$
\mathbf{W}^{\infty}=\lim _{T \rightarrow \infty}\left(\mathbf{L}_{T}-\mathbf{L}_{T-1}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

To show the converse, consider the following exposition:

$$
\mathbf{L}_{T}[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]=\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}^{T+1}=[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}] \mathbf{L}_{T}
$$

Then, let $T \rightarrow \infty$, as follows, so that we know by (40) that $\mathbf{L}_{\infty}=[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}$.

$$
\mathbf{L}_{\infty}[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]=\mathbf{I}=[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}] \mathbf{L}_{\infty}
$$

But since $\mathbf{L}_{\infty}>0$, we obtain $[\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{W}]^{-1}>0$, whence the row viability of $\mathbf{W}$ is obvious.

abstract:
The economy-wide production network, i.e., the monetary input-output
coefficients, will no longer be stable against the general equilibrium
propagation of sectoral productivity shocks, when the substitution elasticities
of sectoral production are nonneutral. The associated network transformation
hence renders nonlinearity in aggregating sectoral productivity shocks into the
economy's output, i.e., Domar aggregation. In this study, we demonstrate the
possibility of production networks being transformed into a singular one. We
also explore the conditions under which the productivity shocks experience
synergism in Domar aggregation.
